newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai B shares end sharply down on cautions.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai B shares end sharply down on cautions.

text.p: Shanghai's B share index ended sharply down on Thursday with investors concerned over the increasing possibility of the securities authorities taking solid measures to cool down the markets, brokers said.
The B index tumbled 4.871 points or 4.96 percent to 93.335 points on volume of 34.349 million shares worth $23.091 million, compared with $29.583 million on Wednesday.

China's official newspapers continued to publish articles warning of risks in the stock markets and a leading economist said the time had come to list currently non-tradable state shares and institutional shares.
One Hong Kong newspaper said on Thursday that China's Ministry of Finance was considering increasing stamp taxes for trading stocks from the current 0.3 percent to 0.4 or 0.5 percent.
Brokers said all these factors had increased investor fears on the possibility of a government crackdown, triggering heavy profit-taking.
"Beijing will not tolerate the abnormally high domestic A share prices and rumours circulating in the market say clampdown measures will be worked out soon," said one broker.
"The index is likely to rebound slightly tomorrow, but the trend beyond that is hard to judge," another broker said.
Of 43 B shares, 42 traded, with 40 down and two flat.
Shanghai Worldbest was the biggest loser on profit-taking, slumping $0.070 or 9.33 percent to $0.680 on volume of 2.1 million shares.
The market barometer Shanghai Lujiazui Finance & Trade Zone Development was the most actively traded for the same reason, down $0.108 or 6.67 percent to $1.510 on volume of 3.6 million shares.
Shanghai's A share index also plunged on the same concerns, with some major institutions which have recently been supporting the market seen off-setting their positions, brokers said.
The index slipped 94.789 points or 6.07 percent to 1,467.861 points on volume of 1.0 billion shares worth 15.4 billion yuan.
The SSE30 blue chip index ended down 320.921 points or 7.27 percent to 4,092.126 points.
Chang Chun Faw Sihuan Automotive was the biggest loser, down 1.96 yuan or 10.01 percent limit-down to 17.62 yuan on volume of 2.5 million shares.
